content.data: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
EASTERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,   :   18-CR-204(NGG)
Plaintiff ,     :
United States Courthouse
-against-            :   Brooklyn, New York
KEITH RANIERE, et al.,     :
June 11, 2019, Tuesday
Defendant.       :   9:15 a.m.
TRANSCRIPT OF TRIAL
BEFORE THE HONORABLE NICHOLAS G. GARAUFIS
UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE, and a jury.
APPEARANCES:
For the Government:         RICHARD P. DONOGHUE
United States Attorney
BY: MOIRA K. PENZA, ESQ.
TANYA HAJJAR, ESQ.
MARK LESKO, ESQ.
Assistant United States Attorneys
271 Cadman Plaza East
Brooklyn, New York 11201
For the Defendant:         BRAFMAN & ASSOCIATES, P.C.
767 Third Avenue
New York, New York 10017
BY: MARC A. AGNIFILO, ESQ.
TENY ROSE GERAGOS, ESQ.
DEROHANNESIAN & DEROHANNESIAN
677 Broadway
Albany, New York 12207
BY:  PAUL DerOHANNESIAN, II, ESQ.
DANIELLE R. SMITH, ESQ.
Court Reporter:  Stacy A. Mace, RMR, CRR, RPR, CCR
Official Court Reporter
E-mail:  SMaceRPR@gmail.com
Proceedings recorded by computerized stenography.  Transcript
produced by Computer-aided Transcription.
(In open court - jury not present.)
(Judge NICHOLAS G. GARAUFIS entered the courtroom.)
THE COURT:  All right, bring in the defendant.
(Defendant entered the courtroom.)
THE COURT:  Where is Ms. Penza?  Is it my vision or
is she not here?
MS. HAJJAR:  She should be here momentarily,
Your Honor.
THE COURT:  Well, everyone sit down, and we will
wait on Ms. Penza.
(Pause.)
MS. PENZA:  So sorry.
THE COURT:  All right.
MS. PENZA:  Good morning.  I apologize.
THE COURT:  Let's have appearances, and then we'll
move on from there.
MS. PENZA:  Moira Penza, Tanya Hajjar, and Mark
Lesko for the United States.  Good morning, Your Honor.
Also at counsel table, Special Agent Michael Lever
and Paralegal Specialist Teri Carby.
THE COURT:  Thank you.  Good morning.
Yes.
MR. AGNIFILO:  Good morning, Your Honor.
Marc Agnifilo, Teny Geragos, Paul der Ohannesian,
and Danielle Smith for Keith Raniere, who is with us this
morning.
Good morning.
THE COURT:  Good morning, everyone.  Please be
seated.
Well, you've been busy overnight.
MR. AGNIFILO:  I don't sleep anymore, Judge.
THE COURT:  Well, I don't sleep at night worrying
about the fact that you don't sleep at night.
MR. AGNIFILO:  I know.  I'll call you.
THE COURT:  No, thank you.
All right, I do not need oral argument here.  On the
issue of the details of the irrevocable trust, the fact of the
trust was, as you pointed out in your letter, has already been
ruled on, right?
MR. AGNIFILO:  Yes.
THE COURT:  So the fact of the trust can come in.
MR. LESKO:  Your Honor, if I may?
THE COURT:  Oh.
MR. LESKO:  Just briefly.  I think we've reached an
agreement that we would enter the fact of the trust and the
total amount available, and not get into which firm was paid
what.
THE COURT:  Available at the beginning of the --
when the trust, in total, when it was created and added to and
added to and added to?
MR. LESKO:  Yes, the total amount available for the
defense.
THE COURT:  I am seeing some visuals here.  Yes?
MR. AGNIFILO:  So what I'd like to do, I think we
have five minutes.  I don't know that I'm comfortable with the
whole amount because it is going to so many parties, and I
don't know that I want to get into all of that.
THE COURT:  Well, figure out how to do it.  Figure
it out.
MR. AGNIFILO:  So if -- but if we can get five
minutes, we might be able to --
THE COURT:  Good.  I want that.  That's good.
MR. LESKO:  Thank you, Your Honor.
THE COURT:  That's a solution, let's try to make it
happen.  All right, that takes care of that.
The two matters that are brought to the Court by the
Government, did you want to say something without going into
details or --
MR. AGNIFILO:  Can we do it at the side?  It will
take really just two minutes.  Can we just do that?  I will be
very, very quick.
(Sidebar held.)
(Continued on following page.)

content.data: (In open court - jury not present.)
THE COURT:  Okay.
All right, I would just point out that the Court has
received some impeachment evidence from the defense, which are
for in-camera review, and we are reviewing that evidence.
MR. AGNIFILO:  Thank you.
THE COURT:  All right?  Thank you.
Okay.  Let's bring in the witness and the jury.
(Witness entered the courtroom and resumed the
stand.)
(Jury enters.)
THE COURT:  Please be seated.
Good morning, members of the jury.
THE JURORS:  Good morning.
THE COURT:  All right, at this time, we will
continue the direct examination of Jay.
You may proceed, Mr. Lesko.
MR. LESKO:  Thank you.
THE COURT:  I remind the witness that she is still
under oath.
(Continued on the following page.)
J A Y,
previously called as a witness by the Government, having
been previously duly sworn/affirmed by the Courtroom
Deputy, was examined and testified further under
oath as follows:
DIRECT EXAMINATION CONTINUING
BY MR. LESKO:
Q Good morning.
A Good morning, everyone.
Q You can pull your microphone close, if you like.
So, Jay, did you have a -- form an impression of how
other women in the community perceived the defendant?
A Yes.
Q What was that impression?
A The impression was that their way -- they had a lot of
adoration, almost a little bit of an obsession, and -- but
they, you know, revered Keith.
Q Were you sexually attracted to the defendant?
A No.
Q So let's go back to the conversation with India, just
before you joined The Vow.  Okay?
A All right.
Q During that conversation, did she tell you that after
joining The Vow you would have to provide additional
collateral?
A I'm sorry, can you repeat that?
Q You provided the four pieces of collateral to join
The Vow, right?
A Correct.
Q Did India tell you that you would, after joining The Vow,
have to provide more collateral or additional collateral?
A She didn't tell me that I would need to when I joined,
but afterwards that was now a thing that I had to start doing.
Q And how often did you have to provide additional
collateral?
A Kind of like rent, you had to submit new collateral the
first of every month.
Q And had you known this requirement, this monthly
collateral requirement, would it have changed your mind about
joining The Vow?
A Absolutely.
Q Why so?
A Because I understood that, okay, fine, you need to
protect the secrecy.  So the first collateral seemed, like,
sensible to a certain degree.
But afterwards, that just -- it was scary.  It's
like, why would I have to keep submitting collateral, and keep
telling them more things about me.  It was -- it was -- it was
really scary.
Q Did you provide monthly collateral?
A I did.
Q And what types of collateral did you provide?
A I provided photos that were either sexy or unattractive,
and more video secrets.
Q Secrets about yourself?
A Correct.
Q And who did you provide this monthly collateral to?
A At first, it was to India.  But then I was invited to
collaborate in a Dropbox, so I directly submitted to there.
Q And what is Dropbox?
A Dropbox is an application where you can store
information, kind of like an iCloud.
Q And who invited you to join the Dropbox, was it a group?
A India invited me, but there was a group in there.
Q Okay.  And could you just explain how the collateral to
the Dropbox process worked?
A Yes.  So you were asked to -- or not asked, you were told
to put in your collateral there on the 1st.  And then shortly
after they said it would be deleted, within 24 hours.
Q I am going to show you what I believe is admitted as
Government's Exhibit 446-R.
MR. LESKO:  Just checking with Ms. Carby.
Yes, okay, this has been admitted.
BY MR. LESKO:
Q And you can look on your screen.
(Exhibit published.)
BY MR. LESKO:
Q I am showing you the -- I'll zoom out.
Can you see that?
A Yes.
Q Okay.  What is the first page of Government's 446-R?
A It's one of the pages on the Dropbox, with different
folders that has brands and workouts.
Q Is this -- is this a screenshot of the Dropbox folder?
A Yes.
Q And do you know who took that screenshot?
A I did.
Q Show you the second page of Government's 446-R.
(Exhibit published.)
Q Do you recognize that page?
A Yes.
Q Is that also a screenshot you took?
A Yes.
Q And so is that the group that you mentioned earlier?
A Correct.
Q And could you name the group, please?
A Allison Mack, Danielle Roberts.  It says "Danielle
exo-eso," which is Danielle Roberts' other e-mail, India
Oxenberg, myself, and Michele.
Q And did you later learn who all these people were?
A Yes.
Q Okay.  Who were they?
A They were people in Allison's little sort of circle, as
well as -- and as well as, technically, my housemate.
Q Okay.  And I am going to show you this -- I think this
second page cuts off at the bottom, so I am going to show you
the bottom of the second page of Government's 446-R.
(Exhibit published.)
BY MR. LESKO:
Q Do you recognize that page?
A Yes.
Q And I think we left off with Michele.
Are there any other names mentioned on that -- on
that page?
A Nicole.
Q And was Nicole also a member of Allison's circle?
A Yes.
Q And is this a screenshot that you took?
A Yes.
Q And just very quickly, the last page.
(Exhibit published.)
Q Do you recognize the last page of Government's 446-R?
A Yes.
Q And what is that?
A It's an invitation to join Dropbox.
It says:  Hi, Jay, India Oxenberg invited you to
edit the folder Collateral iTribe on Dropbox.  And it says:
India said, here is your file to upload collateral.  Once it
is uploaded, it will be taken off line.
Q Okay.  And was that the invitation to join the Dropbox
group?
A Yes.
Q And was -- again, that was your screenshot?
A Yes.
Q Did all of the monthly collateral -- did you upload
collateral to the Dropbox?
A Yes.
Q Did it always remain there or did it get deleted
eventually?
A It got deleted eventually.
Q And did you have an understanding regarding what India
did with your collateral?
A It was a vague understanding, but she said that the
collateral would go into a safe, and that it would be
protected.
Q A physical safe?
A That's what she said.
Q Do you know where the safe was located?
A No.
Q Do you remember a time when collateral was on a
zip drive?
A Yes.
Q And a zip drive, describe what a zip drive is.
A A zip drive is like this little device that holds memory
for computer and files.
Q So could you explain the time when collateral was on a
zip drive?
A Yes.  There was a zip drive that was located in Allison's
apartment, not the house that I lived in.  And Allison wasn't
there, and India asked me if I could grab it for her.  And she
said:  Be careful, it has the collateral, just be safe with
it.
So I went to Allison's house, got it from the table,
and brought it to her.
Q Did that concern you?
A Yes.
Q Why?
A Because it just showed how careless they were being.
Obviously, having my own collateral, it made me scared that
anyone could see it, anything could have happened to it, and
that it wasn't secure and protected.
Q So at this point, when you first start providing the
monthly collateral, what was your understanding of the purpose
of the monthly collateral?
A Well, they said that it was to make your word stronger,
as to uphold your commitments.
Q Did that understanding change later?
A Yes.
Q What was your later understanding?
A My later understanding is that they wanted to blackmail
us with it.
Q So you mentioned that India discussed the master/slave
relationship with you, is that right?
A Yes.
Q So what was your reaction when she -- when she explained
that she was your master and you were her slave?
A Well, she prefaced me and she said that the name dynamic
was very controversial, and that it's meant to raise feelings
for you to go through.  And then she explained that it's kind
of like in karate, master/sensei, yoga, guru, master.
So because she expressed it in that way, because
India to me was just very disarming, I didn't really think
much of it.  I was just like, oh, okay, it's just a word, it's
not gonna mean anything.
Q Are you familiar with the term -- well, you mentioned the
term "circle."
What was a circle?
A A circle, to my knowledge, is the circle of slaves
that -- that had the same master.
Q And whose circle -- were you part of a circle?
A Yes.
Q And whose circle were you part of?
A India's circle.
Q Okay.  And was India part of a circle?
A Yes.
Q And whose circle was India a part of?
A Allison's.
Q Were you aware of other circles in The Vow?
A No.  I knew they existed, I just didn't know who they
were.
Q So let's talk about assignments that you received during
your time in The Vow.  Okay?
A Okay.
Q Did you receive assignments -- you received assignments
from India, right?
A Yes.
Q And I think you mentioned at least one assignment from
Allison?
A Yes.
Q Did you receive additional assignments from Allison?
A Yes.
Q Are you familiar with the term "acts of care"?
A Yes.
Q What is an act of care?
A It was labeled "acts of care for your M," which stood for
master.  And it was, basically, things that you were supposed
to do for your master to help make their life easier, make
them feel good.  Things of that nature.
Q And did you perform acts of care?
A Yes.
Q Did you perform acts of care for India?
A Yes.
Q What did you do?
A I would do things like buy her a mani/pedi or, like, pay
for her massage.  Also, I knew that she liked poems and memes,
so I would send her different memes and poems.
Q What's a meme?
A It's something online, where it's like a picture and like
a quote or something, and something kind of usually funny.
Q Did you give her gifts?
A Yes.
Q What did you give her?
A I got her some jewelry.
Q Did you give anyone else jewelry?
A Yes.
Q Who?
A Allison.
Q Who paid for the jewelry?
A I did.
Q And were you -- were you compensated or paid for any of
these acts of care?
A No.
Q In fact, were you ever paid for any of the assignments
that you completed when you were part of The Vow?
A No.
Q Are you familiar with the term "acts of self-denial"?
A Yes.
Q What are they?
A So it was one of the assignments, where you -- there was
three different acts of self-denial.  One was for one week,
one month, and one year.  And, basically, you just had to give
something up for that time duration.
Q And what was the purpose of an act of denial?
A I was told that it helped build your discipline.  And
also, like, build comfortability with discomfort.
Q Did you perform acts of denial?
A Yes.
Q Could you -- what kind of things did you give up?
A So I really love cookies, and I mean -- so that was one
of the things that I gave up for a month.  As well as the year
one I decided that I wanted to be celibate, so I put that on
there as well.
Q So you remained celibate for a period of time?
A That was on my list, yes.
Q As part of The Vow, did you participate in something
called "readiness"?
A Yes.
Q And what was readiness?
A Readiness was a drill where either India or a random
number would message me with a question mark.  And so at any
time of the day, whether it's 3:00 a.m., 6:00 a.m., you had to
answer to the question mark with RM within one minute or
someone would be punished.
Q And what did "RM" stand for?
A Ready master.
Q And how did you communicate to respond to readiness?
A Usually, Telegram.
Q And what is Telegram?
A Telegram is an encrypted app, where you can self-destruct
messages.  And it's supposed to be, like, private.
Q And did anyone tell you to use Telegram to respond to
readiness?
A Yes.
Q Who?
A India.
Q Now, these punishments that people received, were you
ever told the types of punishments that people received for
your failures?
A India said that sometimes it would be, like, taking a
longer cold shower.  Being woken up in the middle of the
night, like 3:00 a.m., and then have to stand for 30 minutes
and things like that.
Q Were you ever punished?
A Yes.
Q How were you punished?
A Thankfully, India was nice.  So I only had to do -- I
mean, I mainly only did journalling on my failures.
Q As part of The Vow, were you sometimes assigned to do
errands or chores?
A Yes.
Q Could you describe them, please?
A I had to perform services for Allison, as far as cleaning
her house, doing her laundry and things like that.
Q How about groceries, did you help with groceries?
A I did help pick up groceries for her.
Q Were you paid for that work?
A No.
Q When you decided to join The Vow, were you told that you
would have to complete these types of assignments?
A No.
Q Now, we've discussed Allison frequently.
Who is Allison Mack?
A Allison Mack is an actress from the television show
Smallville.  She was also the head of The Source, and she was
my grand master.
Q And you lived with Allison when you were in Albany?
A I lived in the house that she owned, and I would
frequent -- would frequently visit her apartment.
Q So she had two residences?
A Correct.
Q And she stayed in the apartment?
A Yes.
Q And you and others stayed in a house?
A Yes.
Q Okay.  And where was the house again?
A 7 Generals Way in Clifton Park.
Q And who -- you've mentioned this, but who lived in the
house with you?
A Danielle Roberts, Michele, Souki.
Q Showing you what's in evidence as Government's 47.
(Exhibit published.)
BY MR. LESKO:
Q Do you recognize that photograph?
A Yes.
Q Who is that?
A Danielle Roberts.
Q And she stayed in the house with you?
A Yes.
Q Showing you Government's 28 in evidence.
(Exhibit published.)
Q Do you recognize that photograph?
A Yes.
Q Who is that?
A Michele.
Q And she stayed in the house as well?
A Yes.
Q When you first joined The Vow, were you aware of -- that
anyone else was a member of The Vow, other than India?
A No.
Q Did you later learn that Allison was part of The Vow?
A Yes.
Q How did that happen?
A Well, I wanted to join The Source, and so it was very
expensive and I couldn't afford it.  So India suggested that I
talk to Allison, since it was her company, to see if I could
work something out.
So when I went to ask Allison about it, she later
revealed to me that she was my grand master.
Q And what was your reaction?
A I was a little shocked and surprised and a little
excited.
Q Why were you excited?
A Because the way that I perceived her at that time, she
seemed very caring.  As well as she was an actress, and I'm an
actress, so I thought that she would be someone that I could
learn things about the industry from.
Q Did your perception of Allison change over time?
A Yes.
Q How so?
A I would say that it changed from thinking that she was a
good person to then a very emotionally abusive, vindictive,
manipulative, hurtful person.
Q Did you and Allison figure out a way for you to pay for
The Source?
A Yes.
Q Could you explain that?
A So I put either 2 or $3,000 for the deposit.  And we
worked out an agreement, where I would have to enroll three
people and then it would be paid off.  And if not, I would be
able to make payment plans to -- in lieu of the money.
Q And you may have discussed this earlier, but did you have
a payment plan in place for one of the earlier classes?
A Um --
Q The ESP class?
A With the ESP, I paid for all the intensives, those were
paid up.  But I did end up doing Ethos, I believe is what it
was called, and it was like an ongoing ESP class.  And those
were payments.
Q So when you learned that Allison was your grand master,
was it your understanding that you owed her obedience?
A Yes.
Q And did you owe anyone else obedience?
A India.
Q So you've talked about personal information about your
childhood and your history.
Did you reveal that information about yourself to
Allison?
A Yes.
Q Did you reveal it to India?
A Yes.
Q And did you explain to them that -- well, do you
know the -- what is the -- you're familiar with the term
"vulnerabilities"?
A Yes.
Q What are vulnerabilities?
A Vulnerabilities were things that -- I guess, that make
you feel vulnerable.  But it's kind of more like you would
list it, like what are the different -- what are your
vulnerabilities, like --
Q Was that a NXIVM term?
A Yes.  Yes.
Q And did you, in the course of discussions with India and
Allison, indicate that your vulnerabilities were in part
because of the sexual abuse that you experienced?
A Yes, that was a big vulnerability.
Q So let's talk about Delegates for a moment.  Okay?
You explained what Delegates was.  Did you perform
services in connection with Delegates?
A Yes.
Q So briefly, what were they?
A So when I worked for Delegates, I would do the errands,
the tasks, the assistant work, like, the assistant type work,
as well as massages and the Reiki.
And then outside of that, my unpaid work from
Delegates would be I helped India format policies, do some
administrative stuff for her.
Q So that was -- that part of it was unpaid, the
administrative work?
A Yes.
Q And the service work was paid?
A Yes.
Q Do you recall how much you were paid an hour?
A Around 18, $18 an hour.
Q Did you make a lot of money when you were working at
Delegates?
A No.
Q When you were in The Vow, were you instructed to recruit
other slaves?
A Yes.
Q Could you explain that?
A Originally, India just said to make a list in my head of
other women that I thought would benefit from the program,
that would like it, and that would be good.
And then shortly after, the mental list turned into
it needed to be a written list, which escalated into it needed
to be a list that was categorized and so forth.
Q And did you compile information about potential recruits?
A Yes.
Q Could you tell us what that information was?
A It was photos, like from Instagram, just information
about them.  And it was usually verbal, where I'd tell India
and Allison, oh, this girl, she does this, she models, she
wants to do this and that.  And, like, I think she would be
great.  So just like mini profiles on them.
Q Did you show Instagram photographs of potential recruits
to Allison and India?
A Yes.
Q And did they ever comment or react to the photographs?
A They would say, like, she's attractive and she looks cute
and things like that.
Q Did being cute or being attractive, did that seem to be
one of the criteria used to select recruits?
A Not for me personally, but just my friends did happen to
be attractive.
Q How about for Allison and India?
A Yes.  Not particularly India.  But with Allison, she did
show an interest in that category.
Q Did you ever recruit anyone as your slave?
A Yes.
Q Who?
A Val.
Q Who was Val?
A Val was a friend of mine from Los Angeles, who also took
the five-day with me.
Q And what did Val do for a living?
A A model, an actress, and also a dancer.
Q Would you characterize Val as being attractive?
A Yes.
Q And could you please describe how you recruited Val into
The Vow?
A Yes.  Me and Val went to Vancouver together to do
The Source program, where she met Allison.  And I thought she
would be good for it.
I did mention it, but I personally didn't want to
have a slave then because everything was just -- it was just
like a lot to grasp in my own mind of being a part of The Vow.
But Allison, after meeting her said, I love Val, I want her to
be in it.  I think she'd be great for you.
So then I talked to Val and asked different
questions that would, like, prompt her to see if she'd want to
do it; which eventually led to a conversation being had at a
party after the intensive with me, Allison, and Val.
I proceeded to attempt to enroll her and recruit
her, but I failed.  So Allison just jumped in and just pretty
much recruited her right then and there.
Q And was this an instantaneous recruitment?
A Yes.
Q Did anyone reach out to India?
A Yes.
Q How did that happen?
A So we -- after -- Val pretty much wanted to join right
then and there.  And this was a very unorthodox way of being
recruited, which Allison explained, like, listen, you -- no
one ever really knows who their master or grand master is
right away like this.
But because she was so excited to join, we then
phoned in India with a video call.  And she introduced her as,
like, this is your grand master.  Because I was her master.
So Allison was her great grand master.
Q And did you have an impression as to how Val viewed
Allison?
A Yes.  Val had a lot of adoration and admiration for
Allison, you know, because she's an actress and all these
things.  So Val was really excited to be in a more personal
relationship with Allison.
Q So this all happened at the same moment?
A Yes.
Q So Allison basically accepted Val into The Vow at that
moment, is that right?
A Yes.  It was, you're in.  And then, now you've got to get
your collateral.
Q And was this normal, was this a normal procedure?
A No.
Q How so?
A Well, for my personal experience, I only knew that it was
India for a while.  All the information was given to me
periodically over time.  I, basically, felt like I was on an
island by myself and couldn't talk to anyone, except for
India.
Whereas, with Val, she got a lot of information
up front.  And it just happened a lot quickly for her.
Q Did Allison tell Val about the brand or tattoo?
A Yes.
Q What did she say?
A She said that part of it is that you'd get a brand, but
it's like -- she's, like, but really, it's like a tiny tattoo.
She said, it's a sisterhood thing, and that it represents the
symbols of the elements.
Q Did she in that conversation mention that the brand was,
in fact, someone's initials?
A No.
Q Did Allison tell Val about the life commitment?
A She did say that it was a lifetime commitment, like a
sorority.
Q So lots of information about The Vow was shared with Val?
A Yes.
Q Was Val told that any men were involved with The Vow?
A No.
Q So did Val ultimately provide collateral?
A Yes.
Q And to who?
A To me.
Q And what was that collateral?
A One of them was a video that we staged.  So since she was
a model and actress, reputation, we made it look like she did
cocaine.  It was just sugar or, like, flour.  So we staged
that video.  That was one of them.
Q Was there any other collateral?
A Yes.  Allison expressed that it needed to be something
that was heavily weighted, and Val -- Val's sister was
applying for this government official office position.  And so
she wrote a letter and had it notarized, saying that her
sister was a terrorist, along with an envelope to the address
of that office.
Q And did you receive this collateral from Val?
A Yes.
Q How did you receive it?
A The letter she just handed to me.  And the video, I
believe she air dropped it.
Q To your computer?
A I think to my phone.
Q To your phone.
And what did you do with it?
